Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for Scientists to Participate ACS Symposium "Next-Generation Renewable Polymers", San Diego, CA March 25-29, 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL

The development of renewable polymers is driven by the economic and strategic need to reduce the nation's dependence on petroleum based products. It is also driven by the environmental goal of reducing the carbon footprint. This symposium is being organized to cover the latest progress in developing next generation polymers from renewable biomass. Stemming from the biomass starting point, the program will include new monomer development, synthesis and polymerization, the chemical modification of natural polymers, structure property relationships, and new concepts on the synthesis and characterization of materials with new molecular architectures, functionalities and compositions. The request for funding is to cover travel/registration costs of invited speakers which include graduate students and postdocs. The symposium, "Next-Generation Renewable Polymers", will be held at the ACS American Chemical Society Meeting in San Diego CA, March 25-29, 2012.


NONTECHNICAL

The development of renewable polymers is driven by the economic and strategic need to reduce the nation's dependence on petroleum based products such as the vast array of synthetic polymers (e.g. polyethylene, polypropylene) in widespread usage today. It is also driven by the environmental objective of reducing the carbon footprint. The pursuit of these goals has led with increasing effort to the development of new renewable monomers (building blocks) from the biomass, and their polymerizations (chain-like end to end attachments) to yield polymers with desirable end properties, which after usage, can in turn be broken down into the reusable (renewable) materials. Examples of naturally occurring (biomass) sources are vegetable oils, sugars, cellulose derivatives. This symposium is being organized to cover the latest progress in developing next generation polymers from renewable biomass. The request for funding is to cover travel/registration costs of invited speakers which include graduate students and postdocs. The symposium, "Next-Generation Renewable Polymers", will be held at the ACS American Chemical Society Meeting in San Diego CA, March 25-29, 2012.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This fund is used to support scientists to attend a Symposium at the American Chemical Society National Meeting.

The small share (<5%) of renewable polymers in the commercial market is largely due to high cost and inferior performance compared with synthetic polymers produced from petroleum chemicals. Future growth in this arena will rely on the development of judicious synthetic strategies to next-generation materials that involve the design, preparation, and controlled polymerizations of new monomer structures from abundant biomass. In order to further enhance and exchange our knowledge on this emerging area, we organized a Symposium on "Next-Generation Renewable Polymers" at the American Chemical Society National Meeting in San Diego, CA, March 28-29, 2012. Three organizers are Prof. Chuanbing Tang at University of South Carolina, Prof. Marc Hillmyer at University of Minnesota and Prof. Geoff Coates at Cornell University. This symposium was supported by the Polymers Program at National Science Foundation.

The Symposium received 24 oral talks and 17 posters, and separated into 3 sessions in one and half days. This Symposium was one of the most attended PMSE and POLY symposiums in the San Diego ACS Meeting; even it was arranged on Wednesday and Thursday, the last two days in the national meeting. Each of the first two sessions drew more than 150 audiences. Even the last session on Thursday drew almost 100 people. The poster sessions also received strong attention (notes: a few federal laboratories presented posters). Compared to similar symposiums organized in the past at ACS National Meetings. Such large attendance in the last two days of a national meeting is remarkable.

These talks and posters include research in the following areas: plant oils; polyols; furans; olefins; rosin; lactic acid; lignin; cellulose, etc. The renewable polymers include polyesters, block copolymers, thermosets and biocomposites. There are 4 talks from industry, 10 talks given by assistant and associate professors; 2 talks given by graduate students and postdocs; and 3 talks given by foreign scientists. In addition to 3 organizers, 3 scientists were assigned to preside the symposium (one domestic; one foreign and one industry). The NSF grant was used to cover registration of all invited speakers including senior faculty, junior faculty, some graduate students and postdocs, as well as partial travel cost of symposium organizers.

Outcomes

Both academia and industry laboratories recognize the importance of renewable polymers as they can potentially replace petroleum-derived plastics. Therefore, development of polymers from renewable biomass is one of rapidly growing fields in modern polymer and materials science. This Symposium on “Next-Generation Renewable Polymers” provided a platform for the exchange of expertise and ideas within this field and facilitates the discovery of new research directions. The Symposium facilitated exchange and dissemination of information among researchers from various countries and many US academic (including graduate students and postdoctoral fellows), governmental and industrial laboratories. The knowledge gained from this Symposium certainly benefits a variety of participants, including graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and professors as well as researchers from government and industry laboratories. This forum also provided our Nation’s talented graduate students a platform for networking opportunities, such as interactions with academic leaders and industry R & D personnel.
